title: Understanding Postmenopausal Bleeding
subtitle: What it is, why it's done, and what to expect

content.value:
Postmenopausal bleeding is any bleeding from the vagina after menopause. Menopause is confirmed once you have had **no period for 12 months**.

Any vaginal bleeding after this time is not normal and should always be checked. Most causes are harmless, but sometimes bleeding can be a sign of cancer or other serious conditions.

content.description: About 10% of postmenopausal women experience bleeding — most are diagnosed with non-cancerous conditions.

content.value: Understanding the statistics can help put your mind at ease while emphasizing the importance of getting checked.

items.title: 10% Experience Bleeding
items.description: About 10% of postmenopausal women experience some vaginal bleeding

items.title: 1 in 10 Cases
items.description: Only about 1 in 10 cases may be linked to cancer — most are benign

content.title: Why Prompt Assessment Matters
content.description: Most women are diagnosed with non-cancerous conditions, which is why prompt assessment is essential for peace of mind.

content.value: Bleeding can range from light spotting or brown discharge to heavier, period-like bleeding.

items.title: Serious Causes
items.description: Endometrial (womb) cancer or uterine sarcoma, Cervical or vaginal cancer

items.title: Common Benign Causes
items.description: Endometrial or vaginal atrophy, Uterine fibroids or polyps, Endometrial hyperplasia, Infection of the womb lining, Hormone therapy or tamoxifen, Pelvic trauma, Bleeding from urinary tract or rectum

content.value: Many women with postmenopausal bleeding have no other symptoms, but other symptoms may include:

content.title: Important Note
content.description: Hot flushes and other menopause symptoms often ease over time — but bleeding should never return.

content.value: Knowing your risk helps encourage early checks and peace of mind.

items: Family history of endometrial, ovarian or breast cancer
Taking tamoxifen or hormone replacement therapy (HRT)

content.value: These tests are usually quick and done as outpatient procedures.

items.title: Medical History and Pelvic Exam
items.content: Your doctor may ask about your medical history and perform a pelvic exam to assess abnormalities.

items.title: Cervical Smear Test
items.content: If you're due for a cervical smear test, your doctor may perform this to check for cervical abnormalities.

items.title: Transvaginal Ultrasound
items.content: Uses a small probe to view the ovaries, uterus and cervix. This helps assess the thickness of the womb lining and identify abnormalities.

items.title: Hysteroscopy
items.content: A thin camera is inserted through the cervix to view the womb lining. This allows direct visualisation and tissue sampling if needed.

content.title: Don't wait and see
content.description: It's important to get checked straight away if you experience any of the following symptoms.

items: Bleeding with pelvic pain, fever, or foul-smelling discharge
Unexplained weight loss, tiredness, or loss of appetite

content.value: The most important points to remember about postmenopausal bleeding.

items.text: Any bleeding after menopause should be checked
Most causes are not serious and are easily treated
Getting checked quickly brings peace of mind
You can bring a friend or ask for a chaperone at appointments
Support is available every step of the way

content.value: **Don't wait — early assessment leads to better outcomes.**
